During the review, we discussed the matter of what Jack had intended to say and concluded that "exotic" - a rock thrown in from elsewhere - was most likely. Gene suggested "You ought to program a computer to think like Jack thinks, feed it this sentence, and let it finish it. (General laughter) It would be a tough task.
There was no change in the quality of the comm when they hit the crater, suggesting that Houston is still reading them through the LM.

I think we were still on the ejecta blanket of a crater - maybe Bowen (or SWP) - big enough to have penetrated to the subfloor and to have thrown rocks up the slope. So, what I was trying to do was get us away from that and get as far up the hill as we could go. We wound up at the northwest end of the Station 8 area.
The pitch meter has been broken since early in the mission.
Your ability to sense a slope in one-sixth g is not as great as it would be in one g. The extreme, of course, being zero g where you wouldn't sense a slope at all.
On all of the Rover missions, the crews drove up slopes which seemed much steeper once they got off the Rover and tried to stand.
The SEP electronics package has long since shut itself off because of too high a temperature.
TV on.
@alsjurl/Fendell-Bio.pdf"@alsjt>Fendell pans counter-clockwise.
While Fendell is panning counter-clockwise through NE, Jack runs rapidly across the picture, going cross slope to the southeast. He is taking 3-4 foot strides.
Jack is really covering some territory. The fact that the camera is panning in the opposite direction makes it look faster, but he's really moving across that slope.
Fendell reaches the TV's counter-clockwise stop, and then reverses direction.
Gene had not given a mark, having been distracted by the fender clip.
Fendell finds Gene north of the Rover at an appreciable distance. Jack is beyond him, hopping upslope and approximately three times farther away.
With that slope, the kangaroo hop was the only way to move.
You couldn't really go one foot in front of the other uphill, because you can't get your foot high to take that step. So you hop.
I don't recall anybody ever walking up stairs in a pressurized suit.

During the Apollo 16 EVA deployment at @alsjurl/a16/a16.heatflow.html#1212245"@alsjt>121:22:45, shortly after the loss of the heatflow experiments, John steps up onto a 20 cm rock and then down on the other side. This is the only 'step up' and 'step down' that I know of in the Apollo video record.

Gene makes his way cross slope to a boulder due north of the Rover. This is the sample 78135 location as indicated in the Station 8 @alsjurl/a17/a17psrf6-120.jpg"@alsjt>plan map. Jack is climbing farther uphill to another rock, which is the sample 78220 location. Fendell starts to follow Gene, doesn't find him, and goes back to Jack. Gene's cross-Sun stereo pictures of the rock near the Rover are AS17-146- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22365"@alsjt>22365 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22366"@alsjt>22366. Ulli Lotzmann has created a @alsjurl/a17/a17.22365-6st.jpg"@alsjt>stereo-image from the pair.

Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22367"@alsjt>22367 is a "locator" to the Rover. This excellent picture shows the TV camera pointed off to the left and the high-gain antenna pointed back towards Earth, which is over the South Massif. Note that the low-gain antenna, which is partially hidden by the high-gain is also pointed at Earth. The @alsjurl/a17/a17experiment_sep_en.jpg"@alsjt>SEP antenna is behind Jack's seat and the rake for the explosive charges is visible on the back of the Rover. The East Massif is at the upper right. Readers should note the dark blemish on the East Massif foothill above and slightly to the right of the SEP antenna. This is the outcrop area that Gene notes as he and Jack leave Station 8 at @alsjurl/a17/a17.trvsta9.html#1673941"@alsjt>167:39:41.

Fendell finds Jack leaning over the upslope boulder. The plan map of Station 8, extracted from the Apollo 17 Preliminary Science Report, indicates that the boulder is approximately 53 meters ENE of the Rover. The TV record suggests that the boulder is directly uphill from the Rover. According to the mission report, Jack's heart rate peaks at about 167:05 at 122 beats per minute. Gene's peaks at about 167:10 at about 122 beats. These times correspond, roughly, to the times when each of them makes their way back downhill to the Rover. However, the uncertainty in the plotted times is unknown and these peaks may also represent the climbs up to the rock.
I got tired just watching this. We weren't breathing hard; but Jack's voice, when he got up to the rock, was forceful - which we tended to do in those circumstances. You had to blow it out.
Good idea, Jack.

Jack has taken cross-Sun photos of the boulder and is now taking a down-Sun from the right at a distance about equal to his shadow length. His cross-Sun stereos are AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21698"@alsjt>21698, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21699"@alsjt>21699, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21700"@alsjt>21700. His down-Sun is @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21701"@alsjt>21701.

Fendell zooms in on Jack. The rock is perhaps one third of a meter high and two-thirds of a meter across. From later evidence, it is also about two-thirds of a meter long in the direction away from the camera. It is also broader on the bottom than the top.

Jack moves a few steps uphill. He turns his camera toward the Rover, takes a "locator", then moves to the upslope side of the rock. The "locator" is @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21702"@alsjt>21702; and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21703"@alsjt>21703 is another down-Sun.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22368"@alsjt>22368 is a cross-Sun "after" of this sample.
The samples from this rock are described in the Lunar Sample compendium for sample 78235.

Jack flips the rock over with his right foot. It starts to roll toward the Rover, but veers toward the right. Jack follows and kicks it again to keep it going. After a short while, it lands in a shallow depression and stops.
Jack climbs back up to the place where he'd found the boulder, intending to sample the soil which it had been covering. Gene comes into view briefly, going away from the Rover and hopping uphill.

Gene reaches the rolled boulder. Jack is still sampling soil at the original boulder site, this time holding the sample bag low and at arm's length. He is holding the scoop nearer the handle than the head.
Jack goes down to Gene.

Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22369"@alsjt>22369 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22370"@alsjt>22370 are Gene's stereo photos of the exotic boulder, taken prior to sampling. Ulli Lotzmann has created a @alsjurl/a17/a17.22369-70st.jpg"@alsjt>stereo-image from the pair.
Gene moves to the right of the rock and slightly below it, and hits it six times with the hammer. Jack moves upslope of the rock. Gene is raising the hammer to head height.

I still can remember the reverberation through my body when I hit a hard rock like that. Your whole body would feel the impact of that hammer. By this time, I wasn't feeling inhibited from taking good solid swings. But I would have hated to miss it and hit my shin.
I could feel it through the ground, through my feet, like a minor earthquake. And you could see where I moved when you started to swing? I never stood in front of you.
On at least two occasions during Apollo 16, Charlie Duke lost his grip on the hammer. Gene never did.
That's one reason why I didn't use it. I never felt like I had control of it
Journal Contributor Tomas Lundberg notes that Jack did use the hammer once on the Moon, at Camelot starting at @alsjurl/a17/a17.sta5.html#1464152"@alsjt>146:41:52.
They are standing side-by-side. Using Gene's hand for support, Jack kneels to get the fragment, then gets up.
Gene strikes the rock three times.
You notice that I'm standing a little below the boulder. It's something you do automatically.

Human beings are basically lazy. And you naturally find the easiest way to get to it. One thing I noticed back at Station 7 is that, the first time I dropped the scoop, I stepped on it to get the handle up so I could grasp it. The second time, it was over at the rock and I just leaned against the rock and reached down.

That stepping to get the handle is something I do on the golf course all the time. If I happen to drop a sand wedge along the edge of the green - while I'm putting - and I go back to get it. Jack's right, we're lazy and we pick the easiest way out. I always step on the face of that club.
I play golf, but I never do that. My clubs are too good for that. (General laughter)
Jack never needs but one club when he's up to the green, and the putter's got a flat face and it's awful hard...
You don't want to step on your putter, anyway. It's bad luck.
Well, I've got all those high angle clubs with me when I'm around the green.
Jack gets the fragment with the scoop.
Gene drops the bag.
Gene retrieves the bag with his hammer.
Jack pours the sample into the bag that Gene is holding.
Gene hands Jack the sample bag and then leans on the rock so that he can retrieve his dropped hammer. He gets up easily and then strikes the rock seven times.
Gene changes his position from the right of the rock to above it.
Gene changes his mind and shifts back to the right. He hits three blows.
Gene strikes the rock nine times.
From the way that both of them react, it is evident that, after the final blow, a fragment flies off to the right.
Gene goes about 20 meters to the right of the boulder, using a skipping gait as he goes slightly downhill.

I was braking as I was going downhill and then I hopped on two feet coming back up. You can see the degree of that slope. It was a lot of work; I wasn't making much progress." Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22379"@alsjt>22379 from the pan Gene will take at @alsjurl/a17/a17.sta8.html#1670720"@alsjt>167:07:20 shows the footprints Gene's makes during the little excursion, skipping out on the left and hopping back on the right
When Gene and Fendell return to the rock, Jack is examining it on hands and knees.

- (Tongue firmly in cheek) "I had that description written in my checklist, too. (General laughter) And, when I had to go pick up the chip of that boulder, Jack immediately picked up the cue and described it himself. Jack, this was going to be my big moment! You were going to let me do the whole thing, but you couldn't stand it.
From his hands and knees position, Jack gets a sample bag and hands it to Gene.

Jack pushes back off of the rock but can't get his PLSS back far enough to rise. On the third try, he rocks his PLSS back far enough that he starts to tip over backwards. Once the PLSS is over his feet, he rises and hops back under the PLSS to catch himself.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22371"@alsjt>22371 is Gene's "after".
Gene moves the gnomon well away of the rock to the left. He then gets down on hands and knees and flips the rock with his right hand.
The rock rolls about 2 meters, landing with the same side up.
Gene gets up in two tries; then gets the gnomon.

I think that what I had in mind was to get top and bottom samples for solar wind dating. We also had a plan to get soil samples from way underneath boulders, samples that had been shielded from cosmic rays. Bob was thinking about the cosmic ray issue; I had in mind solar wind dating of when the boulder got there. The solar wind doesn't penetrate more than 500 Angstroms (5x10-8 m); whereas cosmic ray secondaries wind up at two or three meters. So we were both right; I just never explained to him what I was doing.
The fragment comes off on hit number seventeen. Some of the blows are audible, unless the sound is being produced by Gene's microphone tapping on the neckring or some similar phenomenon.
Gene gets a sample bag from Jack, who is collecting the fragment with the scoop.
Jack pours the sample into the bag. At some point after he finishes collecting the soil, he takes @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21704"@alsjt>21704 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21705"@alsjt>21705.

Jack uses what might be described as a "hop, skip, and jump" gait. Gene's "after" pictures of the boulder are AS17-146-@alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22372"@alsjt>22372 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22374"@alsjt>22374.
Jack switches to a two-footed skiing stance and makes repeated sounds of skis gliding and, as he goes, trying to hop from side to side.
I'd started out trying to stride downhill. And it didn't work.
Somebody was inspired to put out a "Ski the Moon" poster, this one just a white sphere on a black background.

Fendell returns to Gene. The frames in @alsjurl/a17/a17pan1670720.jpg"@alsjt>Gene's Station 8 pan are AS-17-146- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22375"target="alsj">22375 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22397"target="alsj">22397.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22379"@alsjt>22379 shows the footprints he made when he went to retrieve the sample at 167:02:08.

Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22386"@alsjt>22386, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22387"@alsjt>22387, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22388"@alsjt>22388, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22389"@alsjt>22389 show Jack at the Rover.
Cochise, Shakespeare, the LM, and Van Serg Craters are labeled in a @alsjurl/a17/a17det22387.jpg"@alsjt>detail from @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22387"@alsjt>22387.

Jack's "before" photos of the rake site are AS17-142-@alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21706"@alsjt>21706 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21711"@alsjt>21711. Note that he has used the rake to give scale and a shadow.
Gene's final picture of the exotic boulder, taken before he picked up the gnomon, is @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22398"@alsjt>22398.
Fendell can't keep up with Gene.

When you were hopping, I felt that you could really take off and still have significant control if you anticipated and shock-absorbed your landing. It really was the only way to travel downhill. I think that if you stride on a slope, you shift your weight too much from one foot to the other and, in one-sixth g, once you start to shift your weight your more apt to go kattiwampus (meaning "out of kilter").
Well, you know, it's hard to stride going downhill here on Earth, too. If you go down a twenty degree slope and you start striding, you just don't feel like you've got much control.
Yeah. And when you hop, you can lean back like you do in skis and control your center-of-gravity and not have it out in front of you. (Pause) I can relate to this. This is fun.
Fendell finds them at the one-third-meter-high rock NW of the Rover. Jack is raking; Gene moves out of the picture again.

Gene takes three "before" photos from inside the crater: AS17-146- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22399"@alsjt>22399, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22400"@alsjt>22400, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22401"@alsjt>22401. These show Jack using the rake on the crater rim.

Gene arrives with a sample bag.
Jack presents his SCB.

As can be seen in @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21706"@alsjt>21706, the sides of the rake forward of the handle are made of metal sheet rather than being tines. Therefore, Jack can tilt the rake and turn it into a big scoop.
Jack has just finished pouring a third batch of soil scooped with the edge of the rake.
Jack presents his SCB.

Jack goes SE of the rake site to take a flightline series of photos. He hops north after each picture to get a stereo sequence. These photos are AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21712"@alsjt>21712 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21715"@alsjt>21715.
Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21713"@alsjt>21713 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21714"@alsjt>21714 show Gene sampling in the crater with his tongs.

Gene's "after" of the sample location is @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22403"@alsjt>22403.
Having hopped out of the crater, Gene gets the gnomon.
Fendell finds Jack leaving Gene's seat, headed for the gate.
The level of emotion seems to have dropped off a little bit. We'd been walking up and down that hill for quite a while.
Jack is probably taking "before" pictures of the trench site. Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21717"@alsjt>21717 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21718"@alsjt>21718 are the cross-Sun pictures.
Fendell reaches the counter-clockwise TV stop and reverses pan direction.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21719"@alsjt>21719 is Jack's down-Sun "before" of the trench site, showing Gene in the background taking the @alsjurl/a17/a17-TGE.html"@alsjt>TGE off the Rover.
The reason the camera comes off is that I've got to get close to the fender. The camera keeps you about a foot away from anything. Plus you bang up the lens.

There's something I don't think I mentioned back at Station 7. We were talking about manipulating things more easily. When I was getting samples into a bag, I had mastered how to do that without the camera interfering; where, on the first and second EVAs - like Station 3 - I hadn't figured it out.
If you had to bag something yourself, you had both a vision and an access problem. So you had to find out where your arms met each other above or below the camera.
Fendell zooms in on the rock at the rake site.
Jack's speech pattern has slowed noticeably. He spends time searching for words.
Part of the reason is that I'm tired. It also happens when I'm thinking and trying to talk simultaneously - which I never did very well.
It was a judgment call based on how deep the trench was. You'd take one at the bottom, one is the middle, and a skim off the top.
Jack's heart rate is down to about 90 beats per minute. Gene's is only down to about 110.

I was leaning over the fender, putting pressure on the Rover; and I think I was bouncing it up and down. I think that each wheel had a V-type torsion bar (see @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20453"@alsjt>20453) because the Rover had been folded up for storage in the LM. We didn't have shock absorbers because we would have had dust problems.
The Rover was parked with the rear end downhill, so you were more or less able to stand there looking at it.

Fendell finds Jack southeast of the Rover, trying to angle the scoop head. He had it oriented vertically to dig the trench and now wants to set it at right angles to the handle so that he can sample the trench. Unfortunately, the locking mechanism is now thoroughly fouled with dust. He bangs the scoop head with his hand.
Anyone planning to work on the Moon or Mars ought to have Gene's statement engraved on their forehead and on the inside of their glasses.
Jack gives up on the scoop head and sets it at angle of about 20 degrees from vertical.

This confirms what I thought back when we were going through Station 7 - that the 90 degree angle was something I'd worked out in order to bag samples more easily when I was working alone. I'd hoped to do that here while Gene was doing something else; but, now, Gene's come over and we'll go back to two-man sampling routine.
Gene gets one of Jack's sample bags.

Jack's pictures of the trench are AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21720"@alsjt>21720, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21721"@alsjt>21721, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21722"@alsjt>21722, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21723"@alsjt>21723.
After I got the skim, I just stuck the scoop part way in the wall and scraped upward to get the next 5 centimeters.
Gene has been holding the sample bag at about chest height, thereby forcing Jack to fully extend his arm and raise it over his head to pour.
Gene gets another sample bag and holds it at about the same height; Jack solves the pouring problem by rotating the scoop.
They both turn to look at the trench.

This is an excellent pan.

- (To Gene) "I don't know if you were aware of it or not, but one of the most successful experiments that we conducted was the portable gravimeter. They got great readings all across the valley; and the interpretation is great about the depth of the basalt fill in the valley - about two kilometers deep.
I'm glad; and I do think I remember that. But it was always a pain number one in the butt.

And what it tells you is that the valley used to be almost five kilometers deep before it filled up. The eruption of mare basalt started very soon after the valley formed; but there's as much as a hundred million years of play (meaning 'uncertainty'), there. Serenitatis formed at something like 3.8 billion years ago - something like that - and the oldest basalt that we brought back - from Station 5 - came out at about 3.7 something. Nobody knows for sure how many flows there were or how thick they were. Some of the late basalts in Imbrium are relatively thin - ten meters or so. Some of the layers that they see in Hadley Rille are relatively thin. But whether that applies to the stuff deeper down, nobody knows. You may have had pretty thick cooling units. It just depends on how fast that stuff came out. Probably most of the basalts - in the early phases, anyway - when the flows first start in a basin like Serenitatis, it probably erupts from literally millions of centers. It's not like out on the West Mesa of Albuquerque where you had a single crack and that's where the basalt came up. Initially, a basin like Serenitatis - 500 kilometers across - is fractured to beat all hell and, so, anything coming up from below has an infinite number of choices. And then, gradually, most of those seal off and the later flows come out of a few, discrete, individual eruptions.
They head toward the Rover.

Coming down those shallow slopes is poetry in motion. That's productive use of your time. If you could do something like helicopter skiing - have somebody drop you off at the top and pick you up at the bottom - you could really cover a lot of territory.

In that Essex study, my proposal for the Mars part of it was that you have a Rover that you can run either manually or automated. So if the pair were out working, you could have somebody else, say back at the base or the lander, remotely move it to where you want it. And then, after you leave, it can be operated remotely from Earth or from Mars orbit. I don't think it would be a big weight penalty; all it is, is electronics.
Another sample falls out of Jack's SCB. It comes out in the forward direction and into Jack's field-of-view before it hits the ground. He stops and turns to look.
Jack gets the fallen sample with the scoop and carries it back to the Rover as in an egg-and-spoon race.
Gene is at Jack's seat with the SCB. Jack goes to the gate.
Gene has removed an empty SCB, from under Jack's seat.
The reason, of course, is that Jack is doing most of the sampling while Gene holds the sample bags and then puts them in Jack's SCB.

I think that I was getting so that I didn't quite trust Houston. They kept having us fool around with the SEP and my feeling was that it was probably gone. So I'm trying to prod them a little bit, having just told them that it was 120 (degrees) and my memory, at the time, was probably that that was way outside the limits. Literally, the science room was leading us down the garden path on the SEP, because all this SEP stuff we were doing was wasting time. It had quit working when? Sometime in the first EVA, didn't it? As with the (long-period) gravimeter, they should have bit the bullet far sooner than they did. They knew what the limits were, but they kept having us dust it and tape it!

At 167:59:07, Parker will tell the crew that the SEP receiver turns itself off at 108 degrees. The temperature was 103 degrees at 163:43:51 at the start of the EVA but was 110 degrees by the time they got to Station 6. According to the @alsjurl/a17/a17psr.html"@alsjt>Preliminary Science Report, the receiver switch was - unfortunately - in the Standby position, and no data was obtained during that drive. We note that Jack had reported putting the switch in the On position at the start of the traverse at 164:19:32. According to the @alsjurl/a17/a17psr.html"@alsjt>Preliminary Science Report, some data had been recorded during EVA-2 on the outbound drive to Station 2 and on the inbound drive from Station 4. The crew reported a SEP temperature of 105 degrees when they got to Station 2. We note that the SEP temperature was 112 degrees throughout the inbound EVA-2 traverse, higher than the supposed cutoff, and yet data was supposedly obtained.
TV off.

I was wearing my visor with the lower edge at about eye level and, with it there, all you're getting is indirect sunlight reflected off the surface. And you don't go around staring at the Sun, anyway.
The Sun elevation is about 38 degrees. It was 13 degrees at landing.
This may be a temperature at which physical damage may occur to some of the SEP components. Bob doesn't mention the 108 degree shut off until 167:59:07, when they get to Station 9.
By pushing back on the front of Gene's helmet, Jack can get him rotating back over his knees.
At least I fell off-camera.
I don't remember this particular event but...
I can't believe I don't remember it.
It may be that I just fell on my ass trying to get on the Rover. But I never had problems getting up, and that's why I'm confused as to what this is.
Gene takes a moment to re-read the dialog starting at 167:33:28.
The thing I don't understand is why you couldn't do a push-up.
I don't understand either. I just don't recall that at all.
You know what it may have been? You may have started to kick to get on the Rover, then fell, and you were lying next to the Rover...
Caught by the slope against the Rover.

Yes. Which meant you couldn't rotate backwards. And my gratuitous advice was to get your feet downhill! (General laughter) And you must have had a feeling at some other time - probably Station 6 or 7 - that you were coming close to missing (the seat).

The dialog at 166:48:26 and following indicates that Gene parked the Rover pointed into the hill and without much of a sideslope. This suggests that Gene fell with his feet uphill. To get up by himself, he had to get his feet pointed downhill - as Jack suggested - and, because he had the Rover next to him, getting turned around would have been difficult.

The heading of 267 indicated on the checklist for the drive to Station 9 would have been valid had they done Station 8 at the south end of the planned area. Because they are at the northern end, their average heading will be more to the south.
The 240 heading - southwest - put me on the downslope side of the Rover. And what I'm saying here is that I'm never going to put myself on the downslope again.
Van Serg is WSW of Station 8, beyond the southern rim of Cochise but short of Shakespeare.

During the initial stages of the drive, they are headed more or less southwest, toward the South Massif and Bear Mountain. Jack's traverse photos are AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21746"@alsjt>21746 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21751"@alsjt>21751.
Because of the slope and the craters, we made some wide turns and I just wanted to know where we wanted to go, not how to get there.

The East Massif summit is SSE of their present position. As mentioned previously, this outcrop area is visible in AS17-146-@alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22367"@alsjt> 22367, a photo taken from Station 8. The outcrop area is the dark blemish visible on the East Massif foothill above and slightly to the right of the SEP antenna. As they drive along, Jack takes AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21752"@alsjt>21752, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21753"@alsjt>21753, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21754"@alsjt>21754, which show, they have turned south for a moment, possibly to get around Bowen.
When I was laying out the east geophone line, I had picked out a point on the horizon to walk towards.

They are headed southwest again. Jack's traverse photos covering the drive from here to the rim of Cochise are AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21755"@alsjt>21755 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21764"@alsjt>21764.
Note the change in course.
The replacement fender has started to fail, flapping around and allowing the rear wheel to shower them with dust.
At Houston's request, they turned the LCRU off at 167:31:36 and are transmitting directly from their OPS antennas to the LM.
A hole in the high-gain antenna would indicate that Gene had caught his OPS antenna in it and, possibly, broken it off. Gene doesn't remember having such troubles in training.
Note that, despite Jack's earlier complaints about needless acknowledgments from Houston, here he wants to make sure that they are being heard.

I think that, at some point in the deep, dark past, the geologists at Flagstaff may have called the valley fill the 'plains unit'. You referred to these things as they appeared in the (overhead) photographs - the floor, the plains of the valley. They may have called it the plains unit at one time and then, because we're talking about the rocks - what's underneath that floor - decided to refer to it as the subfloor basalt.

The decision to call the bedrock "subfloor" seems to have come fairly late. The November 6, 1972 edition of the Apollo 17 Lunar Surface Procedures volume (the OPS plan) contains a paragraph headed "Plains Materials" describing the valley fill. There is a footnote to the paragraph title which reads "Or, better, 'subfloor material' to avoid confusion with the more familiar usage of 'plain' meaning the valley floor independent of any stratigraphic connotation." Prior to the flight, the geologists were not sure just what Cernan and Schmitt would find out in the middle of the valley. "The relative evenness of the valley floor at the landing site suggests that a basin-filling unit (plains material) that apparently submerged all but the highest projections of hill-forming (that is, massif) material was emplaced after formation of the trough (that is, the valley). Such fill might consist of volcanic flows (here, they were hoping for younger volcanics over mare basalts), colluvium derived from the adjacent uplands, or sheets of breccia (that is, flat layers of breccia from Imbrium and/or Serenitatis). Similar material may fill nearby uplands basins (e.g. Littrow) or may underlie the topographic bench around the eastern edge of the Serenitatis basin. Plains material is presumably exposed in the bright walls of the craters on the plains. The abundance of blocks in the crater walls and on their rims indicates that the plains material is either indurated or contains large indurated blocks. The large craters may penetrate through the plains material into the underlying massif or (Sculptured) hills units, which may represent their ejecta. Plains materials appear to be younger than the bulk of the massif and hill material and is probably older than the youngest mare fill of the Serenitatis basin. Hence, an age of Imbrium or pre-Imbrium is inferred for the plains material.

From memory, I believe they expected to see "dark mantle material" as the top unit and then had three options for the block-forming subfloor: (1) basalt, or (2) the down-faulted top of the Serenitatis ejecta, possibly partially molten 'sheet breccia', or (3) debris derived from the highlands. Also, they had no idea how thick the subfloor material might be.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21765"@alsjt>21765 shows the approach to the rim of Cochise.
Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21766"@alsjt>21766, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21767"@alsjt>21767, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21768"@alsjt>21768 show the interior of the crater.

The contact is visible in @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21780"@alsjt>21780, dipping down to the right, just above the TV camera and intersecting the right-front corner of the TV camera mirror. The picture was taken at about 167:48:42.

- (Tongue still firmly in cheek) "At 48:50, where Jack says 'I think we've got that relationship', I don't want anyone to misinterpret the fact that we've been on the Moon three days. (Laughing) 'We can't get down to it, but at least we can take a picture.'
It'd be a little hard to have a relationship in those suits, anyway.
This is the block in @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21777"@alsjt>21777.
Gene was still talking about the rock in Cochise, and I was talking about a rock he hit.
We're moving pretty rapidly through this area. If you're going ten kilometers (per hour) and you hit a football (sized rock), you feel it. We put some dents into those wire-wheel tires.

Gene seems to be speculating that the fender has warped. He had tightened the inside clamp at Station 8 and, once he and Jack reach Station 9, they will take another look. At 167:56:11, they find that the fender has, indeed, warped. Gene brought the fender back to Earth. It is currently on display at the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum in Washington. The rear portion of the fender - the last two or three inches that would have borne the brunt of the rooster tail - appears to be badly worn.
And if there is dust between the clamp and the map, it may be slipping.
Jack's photos taken during the drive from Cochise to Van Serg are AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21783"@alsjt>21783 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21788"@alsjt>21788.
Tally-ho is a call made during a hunt when the fox is first seen.

I was getting irritated with Bob for telling me how to get where I'm going. There was a touch of it a page or two ago and you're seeing it again here. What Bob doesn't see is that you don't just go from here to there. I might have to go around something, and I can see why I'm saying 'Damn it, I'm too good of a pilot not to know where I'm going! Don't tell me; just tell me where I need be and I'll be there.' Jack used to get irritated at Bob, and this is the first sign of my irritation.

Throughout these transcripts, Gene has shown great restraint in the face of provocation - from Jack, from Bob, and from the little misfortunes that are inevitably part of such a mission. After three days, he may be getting a little tired and, consequently, a little less willing to ignore minor irritations.

That may be. But, see, now he's infringing on my ability to navigate. He's telling me how to fly. And he doesn't know what the terrain looks like. He doesn't know how many football-sized rocks we're banging into and how many little craters we've got to go through and what the Sun is doing to us and what sightseeing we're doing along the way so that we can get up on the rim of a crater so we can get a picture. Yeah, I'm probably getting tired.

We had been moving at 10 or 12 clicks for a while but we're not moving that fast here. We're picking our way through here, probably at low speed, but as fast as we can get through the block field. With a wander factor of 50 percent, I've got to drive 15 meters to go forward 10.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21789"@alsjt>21789 shows the Van Serg ejecta and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21790"@alsjt>21790 shows the rim.
Gene has scraped the bottom of the Rover on a rock.

I'm out of my seat and I'm walking behind the Rover to see if I can't help Jack with his twisted seatbelt. And, while I'm there, I see the fender curled under. That's where we're getting our dust. And, maybe the other fenders were getting hot and twisted in the Sun.
- (To Gene) "Isn't it remarkable, though, that - even with the transcript - you have no image of looking at those fenders. I run into that all the time.
I can create the image here of what they looked like, but it's today's image; it's not a recollection.
Now, having read this and having heard about my belt, I can remember that now. It's a real image.
Certain things hit me like that, too. But I don't remember seeing the replacement fender curling or the others being warped. I would be kidding you if I said it was a recollection.

Another example, for me, of not having an image is all that floundering around you apparently did beside the Rover (at Station 8). And of me trying to get you stood up. Very faint bells have started to ring. And it didn't come immediately.

Me, too. And, then, I can go back earlier to Tracy's Rock and that whole slope and that whole affair came back to me beautifully. I was there. I remembered it. I remembered working around that rock. I remembered the slope. But, here, I'm losing it.
Gene has rotated Jack's footrest out of the way.
TV on. Jack is at the @alsjurl/a17/a17experiment_sep_en.jpg"@alsjt>SEP; Gene is leaning over the instrument panel from beside his seat.
Fendell pans counter-clockwise, past Jack who may be trying to put some fore-aft creases in the fender to prevent the back end from folding under.

When the replacement fender was installed, the map sheets were quite stiff; they no longer are. Gene brought the replacement fender back to Earth and it is on display at the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum. Ken Glover has provided a photograph of the @alsjurl/a17/a17.underfender.jpg"@alsjt>underside of the fender, with the aft portion at the left. Glover writes: "From memory, I would describe the abrasion as being along the longitudinal axis, and clearly visible as far as about two inches in from one end. It has the appearance of several dark-coloured scratches. Think sand-blaster. There's also some minor fraying of the centre of the map at the very end. I believe the grid lines are still visible because the map is laminated and -- for the most part -- the plastic coating bore the brunt of the scouring and is still translucent. Obviously, the half that was clamped to the fender would not have signs of this sort of abrasion." MIssion photo AS17-137-@alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20979"@alsjt>20979 shows the top of the replacement fender as it appeared at Station 2. Note that there is tape along the shorter side only at the aft end.
Fendell pans past Gene, who has the large dustbrush in hand, headed for the LCRU.

Fendell reaches the counter-clockwise stop and reverses direction. The cuff checklist pages pertaining to Van Serg are @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr21.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-21, @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr22.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-22, and @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr23.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-23. @alsjurl/a17/a17prsci6-123.jpg"@alsjt>Figure 6-123 from the Apollo 17 @alsjurl/a17/a17psr.html"@alsjt>Preliminary Science Report is a plan map showing the position of the Rover relative to the rim.
Fendell examines a small, blocky-rimmed crater near the Rover.
Fendell finds Jack at the gate; Gene at his own seat.

Gene get the gnomon from behind his seat and then gets the dustbrush from under his seat and brushes the gnomon, trying to clean the color chart and the gray scale. After brushing for a moment, Gene taps the color chart with the brush to get some more dust off.
Gene stows the dustbrush and goes to the gate.

Tiptoe Through the Tulips was written by Joe Burke and Al Dubin. It first became popular in 1929 in a recording by Nick Lucas. Over two million copies of the sheet music were sold, particularly after a Lucas rendition was featured in an early 'talkie' motion picture called Gold Diggers of Broadway. The song re-emerged to popularity in 1968 as the signature song of the eccentric, falsetto-voiced, ukulele-playing personality @alsjurl/a17/a17.tinytim.jpg"@alsjt>Tiny Tim (real name Herbert Khaury, 1932-1996, who probably took the stage name from the character in Charles Dickens's A Christmas Carol). Tiny Tim appeared regularly on the popular NBC television program The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson in 1968 and 1969. His fame/notoriety probably peaked with his on-air wedding on the Carson Show on December 17, 1969.
Gene goes to his seat, gets the tongs and attaches them to his yo-yo.
Gene goes past the front of the Rover, headed for the crater rim.
Fendell finds Jack, standing on the rim; Gene has almost reached him.
This is recall to me. This I've seen before. We're just over the rim of the crater.
You can remember walking up and, the first time you look in the crater, there's a lot more crater there than you think there is. I remember Van Serg pretty well.

Gene and Jack will both take pans of the interior of the crater. Jack's @alsjurl/a17/a17pan1682021.jpg"@alsjt>first Station 9 pan consists of frames AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21798"@alsjt>21798 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21824"@alsjt>21824 and will be taken at 168:20:21. Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21802"@alsjt>21802 shows the mound at the bottom of the crater.

Gene has put the gnomon down and is taking cross-Sun "before" pictures AS17-146- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22413"@alsjt>22413 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22414"@alsjt>22414. Jack is taking down-Sun photo AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21791"@alsjt>21791.
Gene starts to move in before Jack finishes his down-Sun picture. He may be having trouble with either the f-stop or focus.
AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21792"@alsjt>21792, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21793"@alsjt>21793, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21794"@alsjt>21794 are Jack's "locators" to the Rover.
Gene has moved beyond the rim crest and is now only visible from about the shoulders up.
Jack gets another sample with the scoop.
It's a big rock - too big for a bag. The bag's on one end and I'm trying to get it down in the bottom of his SCB so that the bag stays attached.
We did that a number of times, to protect or identify a rock.
AS17-146- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22415"@alsjt>22415 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22416"@alsjt>22416 are Gene's "afters". He moved in and to his right between the frames.
Gene seals this sample bag by twisting the tabs, rather than flipping the bag.

Jack moves out of the way so that Gene can take "after" photos AS17-146- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22417"@alsjt>22417 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22418"@alsjt>22418. He stepped to his right and turned slightly to his left between the frames.
They both look around, looking for Shorty-like features and/or pieces of subfloor gabbro.
Jack moves farther beyond the rim crest and goes out of sight.
Jack moves southwest, parallel to the rim, his head and shoulders coming into view.

For clarification, in this paragraph my use of the word 'fragment' is confusing. I had started to use 'fragment' when I should have been using 'clast'. A 'fragment' is sort of a loose piece of rock lying around; these were pieces in a breccia, so they're 'clasts'. I never found out what the light-colored clasts are; I don't think I ever looked into it. There was a mixture of material thrown from the sides of the North Massif and the subfloor-(derived) regolith, so the light-colored clasts are probably the pulverized and reworked material from the North Massif bound up in a matrix of regolith breccia.

According to the @alsjurl/a17/a17psr.html"@alsjt>Preliminary Science Report, the Van Serg "soil breccias" contain "a variety of clasts, including basalts, several types of glasses, some breccia fragments with accretionary coats, and a variety of recrystallized felspathic rocks presumed to be derived from the surrounding highlands." The caption to figure @alsjurl/a17/a17psrf7-4.jpg"@alsjt>7-4 suggests that at least some of "light-gray" clasts are the pieces of felspathic breccias.
Because they are well out on the valley floor and shouldn't be standing on more than a few meters of regolith and/or mantling, an impact the size of Van Serg should have brought up subfloor gabbro.

What Gene's referring to, here, is that this stuff looked a little bit like the blue breccias up on the North Massif (at Stations 6 and 7) because, in appearance, it was dark, bluish-gray with the white clasts. As it turns out - and I don't remember if we came to the conclusion before we left (the Moon) or not - these were those regolith breccias.
Jack finally presents his SCB to receive Gene's glass sample.

Pele's Tears are small drops of volcanic glass, a reference to the Hawaiian volcano goddess and to @alsjurl/ap-geotrips.html"@alsjt>geology field trips Gene took to the island of Hawaii - also known as the Big Island - during training for both Apollo 14 and Apollo 17.

Jack takes down-Sun picture AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21795"@alsjt>21795; Gene gets cross-Sun stereopair AS17-146- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22419"@alsjt>22419 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22420"@alsjt>22420.

Jack turns toward the Rover to take "locator" photos AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21796"@alsjt>21796 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21797"@alsjt>21797; Gene moves in with the tongs to collect the sample.
Jack takes the glass sample, but drops it.
Gene has used the last of the sample bags in the bag holder attached to his camera. We can see the empty holderstill attached to his camera until about 168:19:06.
Gene retrieves the sample with the tongs and Jack takes it again.
Fendell de-zooms and it's hard to see any detail of what they are doing.
Fendell zooms in again. Gene gets a sample bag from Jack's supply.
The sample was just a little too big for the bag.
Gene presents his SCB.

At this stage of the game you get frustrated trying to use your hands. Not that the enthusiasm isn't there. During the first EVA you probably would have shoved it in there but it gets to the point where its difficult. Your dexterity is not what you want it to be. I think you're probably more efficient with your hands; you learn to adapt with your hands as well as with anything else, but now you're fighting (fatigue).
- (To Gene) "In terms of what you could do ungloved, how much less efficient are you?
Less than half.
We then asked Gene if, compared with the start of the EVA, he was taking longer to do tasks or had lost the ability to do certain tasks.

I don't think you lose your ability; you just get frustrated. You're probably smarter in the use of your hands. You know what you can't do, so you don't try to do those things. So you say, 'Well, it's almost done, so I'm not going to worry about the rest of it.' I can almost hear the frustration. Three consecutive days, twelve hours a day in a suit, is a long time.

Just before Jack moves close to Gene we get our last look at the empty bag holder attached to Gene's camera. We get our next look at Gene's camera a 168:20:13. At some point during this interval Gene removes the bag holder and tosses it into Van Serg. It can be seen in a detail (@alsjurl/a17/a17det21805.jpg"@alsjt>222k) from frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21805"@alsjt>21805 in Jack's pan.
Gene takes a step farther away from the Rover, a maneuver that puts him a bit lower than Jack and makes working on the SCB a bit easier.

They will each take a pan, the distance between them giving a wide stereo of the crater. Gene's "after", cross-Sun stereopair is AS17-146-@alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22421"@alsjt>22421 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22422"@alsjt>22422. He stepped to his right between frames.

Gene moves northeast, along the rim, using the loping, foot-to-foot stride; Fendell follows him. Jack's @alsjurl/a17/a17pan1682021.jpg"@alsjt>first Station 9 pan consists of frames AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21798"@alsjt>21798 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21824"@alsjt>21824.
David Harland has assembled the portion showing @alsjurl/a17/a17.1682021_dmh.jpg"@alsjt>Gene and the Rover.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21802"@alsjt>21802 shows the central mound in the crater.

The man-made object in 21802, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21804"@alsjt>21804, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21805"@alsjt>21805, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21806"@alsjt>21806 is a sample bag dispenser. A high-resolution detail ( @alsjurl/a17/a17det21805.jpg"@alsjt>222k ) from 21805 shows the empty dispenser most clearly. Gene may have discarded it at about 168:16:04.
Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21811"@alsjt>21811, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21812"@alsjt>21812, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21813"@alsjt>21813 show Gene taking his pan.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21817"@alsjt>21817 shows the Rover.

Back in Houston, the Flight Director is told that Jack's remaining oxygen supply will limit the EVA to between 7 hours 15 minutes and 7 hours 30 minutes. Gene starts a @alsjurl/a17/a17pan1682042.jpg"@alsjt>photo pan (assembled by Dave Byrne). Gene's pan photos are AS17-146-@alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22423"@alsjt>22423 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#22450"@alsjt>22450. David Harland has assembled the portion showing the @alsjurl/a17/a17.1682042_dmh.jpg"@alsjt>crater.
Fendell pans the TV clockwise, away from Gene.
Fendell examines individual boulders.
Gene previously sang part of "Mule Train" at Station 5 at 146:50:40, also as he was making his way back to the Rover. Fendell finds him halfway back.
Gene reaches the Rover; Fendell zooms in on Jack, who is still at the crater rim.

Gene has taken a measurement with the @alsjurl/a17/a17-TGE.html"@alsjt>TGE on the Rover and will now make one with the TGE on the ground to see if there is any significant difference. The second measurement is 670, 057, 101 at 168:29:42.
Jack gets his scoop and climbs to the rim, having been slightly beyond the crest.

Jack plants the scoop and starts to use the @alsjurl/a17/ap17-KSC-72PC-411.jpg"@alsjt>LRV Sampler which is attached to his yo-yo. As Bob indicates at 167:57:40, because the radial sample is nominally a solo activity, Jack had planned to use the LRV sampler. This is the reason he is wearing it here.
About the only time I ever used the yo-yo was for my LRV sampler.

Jack takes AS17-142- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21825"@alsjt>21825 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21826"@alsjt>21826, which show Gene at the Rover, taking the @alsjurl/a17/a17-TGE.html"@alsjt>TGE off the back. He probably intended these two photos as "locators".
Jack puts the sample in his shin pocket, gets the scoop and moves northeast, rather than radially.

Gene's 500mm photos of the North Massif are AS17-139- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21212"@alsjt>21212 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21229"@alsjt>21229. Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21219"@alsjt>21219 is a good photo of one of the North Massif outcrops.

Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21230"@alsjt>21230 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21248"@alsjt>21248 are photos of the @alsjurl/a17/a17pan1682535B.jpg"@alsjt>easternmost peak on the North Massif and a series down the face. This peak is immediately west of Wessex Cleft.

Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21249"@alsjt>21249 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21268"@alsjt>21268 are photos of the @alsjurl/a17/a17pan1682535C.jpg"@alsjt>North Massif outcrops and boulder tracks. Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21225"@alsjt>21255 is probably the best of these.
The scoop head has just come off the extension handle.
Jack leans on the extension handle to retrieve the scoop head. As he rises, he has to run forward several steps to maintain his balance.

I used the extension handle as a prop so that I could reach down, in a dynamic fashion, grab the scoop and regain my balance. I did avoid sticking the female end of the extension handle in the ground. I didn't want to fill it with dust, so I turned it around and used the handle end. This exercise may be an indication of me getting tired and getting a little bit careless in the way I retrieved that scoop because, if I'd tripped, I'd have been on my face...I would have been in Van Serg. Either it was a very dumb thing to do or I had a hell of a lot of confidence in my ability to do it. I suspect it was the former.

I think that, all through this station, you can see us getting tired. You can go back to the start of the station and see where everything was going 'normal'. But, here, we're saying thing like 'Well, it'll have to do.' And we wouldn't have been saying that earlier.

We sort of hit a wall here. We'd been out for five hours and, while I don't remember it so much in the first EVA, in the second we had this same emotional up and down. I don't know whether we'll come back up again, here. But we did on the second EVA. We went down (emotionally) at (Station) 3 and back up at 4 and then there was a let down again (during the drive from Shorty to Victory) and then back up at 5.

I think this is a combination of the amount of work we did on this EVA on those hillsides and of three solid days of working - and not the greatest amount of sleep. I would predict that if we went out on a fourth day or a fifth day, the total slope (that is, the average trend of their emotional state) - not the up and down of a single EVA, but the total slope - would start darting back up. Who knows? I'm not tired of watching what we were doing, but I sympathize with the amount of effort we were putting out on this third day.

This had to be our most physical day. We rode (and rested) on the Rover for a solid hour getting out to Station 2 on the second day and, here, we only had fifteen or twenty minutes between demanding stations.
And they were demanding stations. We haven't had a piece of level ground (during this EVA) until now
Jack strides back to the Rover.
Fendell pans the TV camera to Gene, who is still using the 500 mm camera.
Gene has put the lens cap on the 500 and is now putting the camera under his seat. He did give a mark on the gravimeter, at 168:24:37.
Here, I was probably thinking about the sample I'd taken up on the rim.
While he was talking, I must have taken a swipe into the dirt near the Rover.
I was still thinking about getting some of the glass balls. I wasn't impressed by the white.
I don't think you'd seen it yet. You were on one side of the Rover and I was on the other. In fact, I think I remember that.
Fendell pans clockwise.

While Gene was reading the gravimeter and was talking to Bob, I must have started to dig a trench. I could dig those trenches pretty fast. In what - maybe twenty seconds - I was able to get several scoops out and I had a flat wall trench.

It wasn't obvious at this point in the review whether Jack had been able to get the scoop back on the extension handle. Momentarily, Fendell will find them and, as soon as he does, it is immediately obvious that Jack is using the scoop rather than the LRV Sampler.
AS17-142-21827 to 21829 are Jack's photos of the Station 9 trench.

- (Laughing) "It doesn't take much to get your enthusiasm back up. Because, all of a sudden, there's a whole different tone in my voice. It may be a combination of having seen something different and the fact that Houston's now put some pressure on us to get out of there.

It also shows that you've got to have someone on the spot to make a decision. They're saying get out and we're saying 'Sorry, guys, we're not going to get out for five minutes because we've got something we think is worthwhile.' That's the way you have to operate. The ground is an advisor; it's a flight planner; it's a lot of things. But you've got to make the decisions of what you're going to do with your time.

I then mentioned a conversation with Conrad and Bean in which they indicated that they had trained very tightly to their timeline. They had a great deal to do, in a small area, and not much time to be on the Moon. I noted that, on the longer missions, the tasks were not spelled out in such detail and asked for comments.

It's a natural maturation of the program. More time gives you more flexibility. But, as Jack mentioned earlier, we never did have a nominal station. They give you thirty minutes and they want an hour's worth of work. It's just normal. Using the time is never a problem.
Fendell finds them west of the Rover. The lighting conditions emphasize that Gene has gotten very dirty by this late in the mission.
Gene gets a sample bag from Jack's camera holder.
Fendell zooms in on the trench.
Houston has been discussing a possible extension at this station. However, the Flight Director is concerned about tired hands.

While we were doing this sampling, in the background on the video tape we can hear Gerry Griffin acting like a Flight Director. In trying to be objective about what we've seen here at this station, I thought he might have taken hold of the apparent fatigue a little bit sooner.
Fendell pans clockwise.
Jack needs to take occasional photos documenting the traverse.
Fendell finds both of them at Gene's seat.

I don't know why I remember this, but I think that the DSEA - which was the SEP recording tape - had a locking bolt that came up into a slot with a little winged, butterfly-shaped bow that you screwed down. And I think that what Gene found is that it was just sitting in there - that the bow had tripped.
Gene goes to Jack's seat.

I think that ground is showing some sensible decision making, here. Their taking new information - namely the white underneath the dark that we just discovered and sampled - and deciding to take a double core here, rather than taking pot luck at some other place. A bird-in-the-hand type philosophy.
Gene takes the scoop off the extension handle.
I think this exchange is another symptom of my being tired.
It was a symptom of being tired. My willingness to do the core had nothing to do with my geologic expectations. I was just saying, 'Whatever we're going to do, let's just get on with it'.
Had I really been thinking, (I would have realized that) those rocks are so soft you'd go through them (with the core) anyway.
Jack gets a core tube out of Gene's SCB. Gene is holding an upper section.
They connect the core tube sections.
Gene goes around the front of the Rover; Fendell follows him.
Jack wants to put the explosives package somewhere where it won't get in Gene's way as they leave.
Fendell finds Gene hammering the drive tube, north of the Rover.
Just as Bob says this, the tube penetration comes to a halt.
After two more hammer blows, Gene seems to break through whatever was blocking progress and the core begins penetrating again.
Gene stows the hammer in his shin pocket.

Frames AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21836"@alsjt>21836 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21858"@alsjt>21858 are @alsjurl/a17/a17pan1683947.jpg"@alsjt>Jack's second Station 9 pan taken near the Rover.
Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21836"@alsjt>21836 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21837"@alsjt>21837 show Gene hammering the core.
Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21838"@alsjt>21838 shows the seismic charge.
David Harland has assembled frames @alsjurl/a17/a17.1683949_dmh1.jpg"@alsjt>21836 to 21841, which show Gene collectiing the core.

Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21857"@alsjt>21857 shows Gene with the core at the back of the Rover. A @alsjurl/a17/a17det21857.jpg"@alsjt>detail gives good views of the charge transporter, the extension handle attachment to the upper drive tube, and the replacement fender.
David Harland has assembled frames @alsjurl/a17/a17.1683949_dmh.jpg"@alsjt>21856 and 21858, which show Gene carrying the core tube back to the Rover at about 168:40:28.

Gene pulls the core out of the ground with his left hand. It takes about 12 seconds. Gene then rotates the core so that it is parallel to the ground and examines the outside from the top down toward the bit. As he finishes the examination, he lightly touches his forefinger to the soil exposed at the tip.
Gene goes to the Rover, using his forefinger as a core plug.
That is, Gene has capped the bit end of the lower section.
Fendell finds them at the gate.

Gene goes to Jack's seat with the lower section. He gets a cap and screws it on, then puts the section under the seat. Jack turns to present the left side of his PLSS. Gene gets a cap for the upper section that Jack has been holding.

Gene is talking about the pins that hold the extension handle to the upper section. This is the extension handle which is normally attached to the rake. Gene gets the rammer and goes to Jack's seat; Jack goes to the gate.
Jack giggles at the thought.

Fendell is looking in the direction of the marker flag on the Explosives Package. It is orange. When Fendell first pointed the TV at the horizon beyond it, he was at minimum zoom and the flag was just a few picture elements across and, therefore, just a faint blur of color. After a while, someone noticed the patch of color and Fendell zooms in to see what it is. Because it is actually in the very near field, rather than in the far field, zooming only blurred it more.

There are prior references to the "Italian Flag" at @alsjurl/a17/a17.clsout2.html#1470136">147:01:36 during the drive back to the LM at the end of the second EVA. The flag is shown here in AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21837"@alsjt>21837. The actual color is international orange.
I think that it was Bob who told me that they really didn't have any idea - when he started to call us - of what that was. None! And I don't think I've ever seen this sequence in a NASA tape.
I have never seen this picture until just now. Never. Never!
TV off; static

Gene goes to the front of the Rover to take pictures of Jack jumping in his seat. The three pictures are AS17-134- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20452"@alsjt>20452, @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20453"@alsjt>20453, and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20454"@alsjt>20454.
It was sort of a target of opportunity. It was just one of those (unplanned) things you do. And it's a pretty good picture.
I did whatever I'd done the last time (at Station 8 when he fell as he tried to mount the Rover) - got my foot caught on something, or whatever.

Because of the four-wheel steering, Gene will turn toward the charge to get around it. If he turned left, the back wheels of the Rover would turn toward the charge - although, in this case, the separation is substantial.

Jack's first photo of the drive back to the LM is AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21859"@alsjt>21859, which shows a distinctive boulder at the right side of the image. The same boulder can be seen in AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21847"@alsjt>21847, which is a frame from Jack's pan.

Cuff checklist page @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr24.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-24 shows the planned traverse to Station 10. For completeness, pages @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr25.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-25, @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr26.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-26, @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr27.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-27, @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr28.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-28, and @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_cdr29.gif"@alsjt>CDR-29 cover the planned drive to Station 10, the planned activities at that station, and the drive back to the LM.
AS17-143-21860 to 21863 cover the next portion of the traverse.

AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21864"@alsjt>21864 shows Gatsby from the east. Frame @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21865"@alsjt>21865 is taken after Gene turns to give them a better view into the crater.

AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21866"@alsjt>21866 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21867"@alsjt>21867 are additional pictures of Gatsby. AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21868"@alsjt>21868 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21870"@alsjt>21870 are taken as they drive south around Gatsby and then drive toward Sherlock.
Bob is referring to the contour map on the back of the traverse map.
AS17-143-21871 to 21873 may be taken at about this time.

I think I was using 'alpha' or 'A' for 'Apollo', and Bob was using 'Bravo' in the sense of 'job well done'. It's possible that I had something going with those guys. It's possible, but I just don't remember.
- (Laughing very loudly) "That I remember!!
- (Laughing) "The fastest we went was coming off of the Scarp and, for a short period of time, we did hit 17 clicks (kilometers per hour). But, here, I think we set this one up.

Sometimes in my talk, I say that, in normal terrain you can push the Rover up to 10 to 12 clicks. But that, one time going downhill, we had it up to 18 kilometers per hour and regretted it. And we were bouncing.

But I do think that we set this one up; we wanted to go down in history. I was with Johnny Rutherford (an American race driver of Indianapolis or 'Indy'-type cars) one time. I'd asked him to give a talk about a year or two ago. Someone asked him a question and he was talking about being the fastest human or having the fastest time at Indy or something and I got up there and said that I didn't think that that was right. I said, 'I drove a little race car about 17 kilometers per hour on the surface of the Moon, and that makes me and Jack Schmitt the fastest race car drivers in the world. And he said, 'Well, what are you talking about?' And I said, 'When you add 17 kilometers per hour to the rate the Moon travels around the Earth..." (General laughter

Journal Contributor Brian Lawrence notes, " Rutherford was born in 1938, drove in twenty four Indy 500s, his rookie year being 1963. He won in 1974, 76, and 80. I suspect that the occasion Gene mentions was soon after the 1973 event, because Johnny set a new one-lap record of 199.071 mph, and a 4-lap record of 198.413 mph driving a Gulf McLaren. Both records lasted until 1977 when they were beaten by Tom Sneva." Brian and I are both race fans, he of Formula 1, primarily, and me of Indy-cars, primarily.
AS17-143-21874 to 21882 are Jack's pictures of their approach to the big block near Sherlock Crater.

I have marked a likely candidate for this boulder on a high-resolution scan ( @alsjurl/a17/a17GatsbySherlock.jpg"@alsjt>1.5 Mb ) made from a print of AS17-2309. The candidate boulder is marked '168:57:10'. The distances from the photo stop made on the east rim of Gatsby at 168:51:03 and from the sample stop just north of Sherlock at 168:59:46 are consistent with the travel times. See, also, Figure 7e ( @alsjurl/a17/a17profpap-f7e.jpg"@alsjt>0.8 Mb ) in the Professional Paper.

'Evenly sorted' is an oxymoron. 'Sorted' implies that there's a non-random organization. 'Evenly sorted' means it's random. It's not very good jargon. It's used; but it's not very good jargon. And by 'massive', I mean that there is no other organization - the material within the vesicles didn't seem to have phenocrysts or alignments or anything like that.
Unlike the LM, Geophone Rock, Turning Point Rock, and Tracy's Rock, this boulder is not readily apparent in the high-resolution pan camera image of the landing site taken from the Command Module.
AS17-143-21883 to 21885 are the next in Jack's sequence of traverse photos. 21883 may show the Sherlock rim.
AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21886"@alsjt>21886 is Jack's photo of the large block on the Sherlock rim.

AS17-143-21887 to 21890 are taken during the approach to the next Rover sample stop. Note the distinctive rock above the TV camera in @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21890"@alsjt>21890 and compare with Gene's photo AS17-134- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20455"@alsjt>20455.

Two or three kilometers away on either side, we're surrounded by highlands - high mountains with entirely different kinds of rocks. Yet I don't think we ever recognized any fragments of the breccias from the mountains. You would have thought that some would have been thrown in there in 3.8 billion years; but we just didn't see any. The interpretation, now, is that, at about 3.5 (billion years ago), there was a mantling of the dark pyroclastics with a little bit of orange soil mixed in. And then, over time, that's just been reworked into the soil and it's so fine grained that it may have absorbed fragments into it.
I asked about the depth of the regolith on the massifs, wondering if it was deep enough that you wouldn't get a lot of ejected fragments.

It's deeper (than on the valley floor), but it should give you some instant rock - some regolith breccias. And those would survive if they were hard enough. They find stuff (from the Massifs) in the soil, but no coarse fragments.
Jack's photos taken during the final approach to the sample site are AS17-143-21891 to 21893.
During our review, Jack noted that, at this point, his voice quality changed dramatically as he looks down to see what he's doing, getting his chin as far down on his neck as possible.
That is, Jack wants Gene to turn toward the north so that there is no Rover shadow on Jack's side of the vehicle.
They both take documentation photos. Jack's is AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21894"@alsjt>21894 and Gene's is AS17-134- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20455"@alsjt>20455.
I think I was probably going pretty slow. As long as you don't hit those things hard and fast, you're okay. So I just went over it with the wheel.
AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21895"@alsjt>21895 to @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21905"@alsjt>21905 are Jack's photos taken during the next few minutes.
Obviously, I was just running something through my mind out loud and (when) it didn't make sense to me, I decided to forget about it.

As shown in AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21906"@alsjt>21906, Gene takes a turn to the south, probably to get around a crater. Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21907"@alsjt>21907 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21908"@alsjt>21908 are subsequent traverse photos.
I have an image of what the Challenger looked like coming back from Station 5 on the second EVA, but not from here.
Me, either.

They both take pictures. Jack's is AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21909"@alsjt>21909. The LM is just to the left of center, as indicated in a @alsjurl/a17/a17lbl21909.jpg"@alsjt>labeled version. Gene's photo is AS17-134- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20456"@alsjt>20456. The LM is just under the angle of the high-gain.

Bob's reference to "last night" may be an indication of how tired he is, as well. I haven't been able to find a discussion of this EP deployment during the closing stages of EVA-2 or during the subsequent discussions in the cabin. More likely, Bob is referring to the EVA-3 pre-brief conducted while Gene and Jack were eating breakfast. It is now about 10:30 in the evening in Houston and, like everyone else, Bob has had three long days.

AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21910"@alsjt>21910 seems to be Jack's only traverse photo taken between the spot where they saw the LM and the fractured boulder at San Luis Rey mentioned at 169:07:24.

AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21911"@alsjt>21911 may show the fractured rock at San Luis Rey. Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21912"@alsjt>21912 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21913"@alsjt>21913 are taken during the remainder of the drive up to the point where Jack gets off west of the SEP transmitter array to deploy a seismic charge.

Cuff checklist page @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmpcdr28.gif"@alsjt>LMP/CDR-28 shows a sketch of the complex. Compare with a @alsjurl/a17/a17prsci6-3det.jpg"@alsjt>detail from Apollo 17 @alsjurl/a17/a17psr.html"@alsjt>Preliminary Science Report Figure 6-3.

After they unload the Rover at the LM, Gene will drive the Rover out to its final parking place near the SEP transmitter, a spot far enough east of the spacecraft that the TV audience on Earth can watch the launch. This final parking place is called the VIP site, recalling the close-in viewing stands at the Cape reserved for Very Important Persons.

The range reading of 0.2 indicates that the Rover navigation system thinks they are 150 to 250 meters from the SEP transmitter, an error of about 100 to 200 meters, depending on whether or not the indicator is about to click down to 0.1. This close to the SEP, the difference between the bearing readout of 221 degrees - about SW - at the true bearing of about 270 is almost meaningless. Further information of the cumulative range error becomes available when Gene gets back to the LM at 169:18:00.
It worked great. They knew where we were, even when we didn't.
I'd probably noticed this rock during the first EVA when we were laying out the SEP. It was non-vesicular and fine grained, which was what attracted my eye.

This rock is @alsjurl/a17/a17Sample70215.pdf"@alsjt>sample 70215, an 8.11 kilogram piece of fine-grained basalt. It is the biggest rock that they brought back. Jack will collect it at @alsjurl/a17/#1691501"@alsjt>169:15:01.
What Jack doesn't realize is that the rake, the scoop, and both of the extension handles have fallen off the Rover, somewhere between here and Station 9.

The geopallet is attached to the Rover chassis behind the seats. There is a latch behind Gene's seat and, behind Jack's seat, the pallet is attached to the geopost. If the latch on Gene's side was unlocked, then the pallet could pivot. The "gate", in turn, is attached to the pallet and is also hinged behind Jack's seat. The gate latch has been giving them trouble throughout the EVA and it seems most likely that it is the gate that is swinging open.

The rack containing the explosive packages is mounted behind Gene's seat. In the picture Gene took at Station 9 of Jack mounting the Rover - AS17-134- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20453"@alsjt>20453 - it is visible below the rake.

AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21924"@alsjt>21924 is Jack's "locator" from behind the Rover. Note that the rake and scoop are missing, having fallen off at some time since they left Station 9. The Big Bag is mounted on the pallet. Gene's comparable photo, taken from his Rover seat, is AS17-134- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20457"@alsjt>20457. The SEP transmitter is to the right of the high-gain mast.
For future reference in determining the distance of the final Rover parking place from the LM, EP-2 is about 190 meters from the spacecraft.

- (Comparing the EP-2 "locator" with the VIP site "locator", AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21932"@alsjt>21932) "It looks like Gene parked the Rover about a third closer (actually about twenty percent) and, when that thing went off, the back of the Rover must have gotten splattered a little bit. This business of the explosives packages brings up the question of long duration activities on the Moon away from a radiation shelter and what you would do in the event of a solar particle event. We didn't worry about them because we figured that the probability was low enough that we'd just deal with whatever happened.
And we couldn't have dealt with big ones.

But if you're going to have a lunar base, you're going to have some kind of emergency capability. You'll have maybe a half hour - possibly as much as an hour - warning, although nobody's quite worked that out yet. But one way to deal with it is to excavate a trench with a linear charge, drive the Rover over it (to form a roof), get into the trench and, with an umbilical, attach yourself to Rover consumables. You have the walls protecting you and you can even think about putting low molecular weight material (e.g. water) in the floor of the Rover to give you additional protection. It's a neat idea; and it actually comes from Jim Blacic up at Los Alamos. And the reason I brought it up here is that people say, 'Explosives on the Moon!?' And you've got to remind them that we've already done that.

I was just thinking that it would be neat to be able to take a little tour back to the valley of Taurus-Littrow and see what things look like. See where the Ascent Stage hit (on the South Massif); see where the Rover is splattered with material from that bomb; see the remnants of the Descent Stage. Even if you had to do it remotely, I would really like to see what that area looks like.
Because Gene removed the data storage unit at Station 9, the SEP experiment is now non-functional.
I think that I didn't bother with the seatbelt because I was going to get off in just a little ways to pick up the big rock.
I think I tried to do some solo sampling on the first EVA, and I think I'd dropped a sample bag.
AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21925"@alsjt>21925 is taken at about this point and shows the dark rock. Note the Rover tracks and, beyond the LM, the ALSEP.

The sample is @alsjurl/a17/a17Sample70215.pdf"@alsjt>70215, an 8.1 kg fine-grained basalt, the largest rock Apollo 17 brought back to Earth. AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21926"@alsjt>21926 is Jack's documentation photo of the sample location. AS17-134- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20458"@alsjt>20458 is Gene's "locator". Note that the Rover tracks in the foreground are not particularly dark. Frames @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20459"@alsjt>20459 and @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20460"@alsjt>20460 are two subsequent photos Gene takes as he drives closer to the LM, and these show dark tracks.
It's a classic, old comedy routine. You start to pick something up and you kick it out ahead of you.
As described at 169:46:26, pieces of this rock were later put on public display and are the only pieces of the Moon that the public has ever been allowed to touch.
This is a reference to Gene's discovery of a piece of brown packing material near here during the SEP deployment. The details are given at 123:03:34 and 123:28:18.
Jack is thinking about the sample he collected at Van Serg with the @alsjurl/tools/judy80.gif"@alsjt>LRV Sampler and, just for a second, forgot that he had put it in his shin pocket at 168:25:35.

Gene is wearing one pair of tongs on his yo-yo. Jack is getting a second pair off of the gate, rather than getting Gene's as he did at the end of EVA-2. See the discussion at 147:06:38 and following, and at 147:48:55 and following.

The readings are the bearing to the SEP transmitter, the distance driven, and the range from the SEP. Usually, Gene inserts a decimal point into the range readout but, here, gives the raw, three-digit reading rather than saying "0.1" kilometers. The actual bearing is about 080 and the range is about 150 meters. Because the distance from the LM to the SEP is short, the bearing error is meaningless. The range reading of 0.1 means that the navigation system thinks the range is between 0.05 and 0.15 km, an indication of a relatively small error.
Gene may be having trouble with his seat belt.
The battery 2 temperature gauge has malfunctioned, hence Gene's "forget 0".

Gene and Jack have driven a total of 36.0 kilometers and have used 57.2 amp-hours -plus another 14.8 amp-hours for LCRU operations - out of the 242 amp-hours available. Their average use rate of 1.58 amp-hours/km is similar to the 1.67 am-hours/km used on Apollo 15. The use rate on Apollo 16 was nearly twice as much due to an unexplained malfunction.
I believe they were looking for Descent Engine effluents and, to my knowledge, they were never able to detect any.
TV on.
Jack is stowing drive tubes at his seat. He is on @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmp29.gif"@alsjt>LMP-29 and Gene is on @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_cdr30.gif"@alsjt>CDR-30.

Jack takes SCB-7 to the ladder footpad and then returns to the Rover. He is now on @alsjurl/a17/a17eva3_lmp30.gif"@alsjt>LMP-30. Note that the SCB on Jack's PLSS is not attached at the bottom. @alsjurl/a17/Fendell-Bio.pdf"@alsjt>Fendell has been panning left. Note that there is nothing on the ladder hook. Fendell stops pannding with the MESA in view. The ETB is hanging from the front of the MESA on the left.

Fendell has panned right and finds Gene near the ladder, reading his checklist. The bag bag is one the ladder hook, swinging. Evidently, Gene has just hung it there. EVA-3 photo AS17-143-@alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21924"@alsjt>21924, taken at @alsjurl/a17/a17.trvlm3.html#1691228"@alsjt>169:12:28 after Jack dismounted to deploy EP-2, shows the big bag mounted in the forward surface of the geopallet.

Jack takes another SCB to the footpad; Gene reaches to switch to his auxiliary supply of feedwater. In order to reach back, Gene brings his arm up to about chest height and slightly adjusts the lateral orientation before he swings it back. On this first attempt, he can't quite reach the switch, brings his hand forward about a foot, and then swings it back again, this time successfully getting hold of the switch.
That's not atypical. That's what you had to do to work against the stiffness in the bearings.
Gene still has to get Jack's SCB off.
SCB-3 was on the accessory staff next to the control panel. Gene and Jack go to the Rover.
Fendell is looking at the pile of equipment at the ladder.

Jack's EP-2 "locator" - AS17-143- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#21924"@alsjt>21924 - shows that the rake and scoop were gone at that time. A comparison with AS17-135- @alsjurl/a17/images17.html#20542"@alsjt>20542 suggests that the extension handles came out of the mounting brackets.
